awd_titl_txt: Digitization TCN: Collaborative Research: Documenting marine biodiversity through Digitization of Invertebrate collections (DigIn)
awd_abstract_narration:
For two centuries, America has amassed an unparalleled collection of specimens from exploring the world's oceans. They were pulled up with nets, scooped up from seabeds with grabs, and hand-collected by divers, all contributing to a library of biodiversity that captures the state of life in the ocean - year after year, decade after decade. The broadest evolutionary scope of those collections is in the marine invertebrates, animals without backbones - sea stars, corals, worms, jellyfish, crabs, and thousands of other animals. That library of preserved marine invertebrates is our essential guide to the diversity of ocean life across the globe. And because they encapsulate data from the moment they were picked up, these institutional collections also act as a time machine, letting us use the past to understand how our present will become the future. But there is a problem - vast numbers of these specimens are essentially invisible outside of a tiny community of museum specialists. The only record of these specimens' existence is on labels enclosed in the jars with the preserved animals or in paper logbooks on a shelf. These specimens will remain nearly undiscoverable on museum shelves until their core descriptive information is made digitally available. Therefore, this project will create public digital records for over 7.5 million specimens from our nation's legacy of marine exploration, thereby making the immense investment in the specimens' acquisition available to 21st Century biodiversity and ecosystems research. Because these specimens provide a visible and tangible window into our oceans' enchanting biodiversity, this project will involve STEM educators and student educators in the digitization effort, so that they will be able to reflect their science experiences directly back to the classroom. The public will be involved virtually, by contributing transcription of specimen label data. 

Digitization of alcohol-preserved marine specimens has never been carried out on this scale. A major challenge lies in the location of the data: written, typed, or printed on labels in the jars with the specimens. In many cases, that will require opening the jar, extracting the label, and either transcribing it directly or photographing it for later transcription - for hundreds of thousands of jars. The immediate participants in this program will digitize most or all of the marine invertebrate collections at nineteen institutions across the country, more than doubling the number of digital records for marine invertebrates in the U.S. All data will be publicly available through existing data portals, including iDigBio.org, using standardized data formats, thereby dramatically enhancing the accessibility of biodiversity data for comprehensive, systems-based analysis of ocean ecosystems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Natural history collections serve as vital records of Earth�s biodiversity, preserving specimens that document species distributions, environmental changes, and evolutionary history. However, many of these collections remain difficult to access, limiting their utility for research, conservation, and education. Digitization efforts address this challenge by making specimen data, images, and other biodiveristy data and media publicly available via the web. The DigIn Thematic Collections Network (https://www.digin-tcn.org/), a collaborative effort involving 19 U.S. institutions, sought to transform access to marine invertebrate collections by digitizing and mobilizing over 800,000 lots representing more than 7 million specimens. This project aimed to georeference digitized records, standardize nomenclature across databases, and make over 400,000 images of marine invertebrates accessible through online portals such as iDigBio, GBIF, OBIS, and InvertEBase. Through DigIn, the Alabama Museum of Natural History (ALMNH) has focused on digitizing its Invertebrate Zoology collection (ALMNH:Inv), which encompasses all animals without backbones except terrestrial arthropods and includes specimens from all over the world with particularly good representation of invertebrates from the Gulf of Mexico and Antarctica.

Through DigIn, ALMNH:Inv aimed to perform quality control on our legacy FileMaker Pro database and make these data publicly accessible via Arctos (https://arctos.database.museum/almnh_inv), digitize at least 5,250 specimens in our backlog of uncatalogued material and collected during new field work, integrate ALMNH:Inv specimen records into the leading global biodiversity data repositories (iDigBio, GBIF, OBIS, and InvertEBase), and improve the organization and accessibility of the collection. To date, the ALMNH Invertebrate Zoology collection has digitized a total of 24,922 specimen records that are publicly available via Arctos with more on the way. These records are also searchable via the iDigBio, GBIF, OBIS, and InvertEBase aggregators. Automated synchronization between Arctos and these databases takes place monthly, ensuring up-to-date data as we continue to expand our collection. Although ALMNH:Inv did not specifically propose to image specimens within the scope of this project,15,241 specimen images � mostly of Antarctic marine invertebrates � were captured and made publicly available via Arctos (and are also accessible via e.g., GBIF). The community fostered through our regular Zoom meetings and annual workshops has led to valuable exchanges of knowledge on best practices in specimen digitization and beyond. This vibrant community will undoubtedly continue to interact beyond the life of the grant. Thanks to knowledge gained from DigIn peers and the Arctos community, ALMNH:Inv now has an efficient digitization workflow and a training program for new members of our team. Additionally, custom shell scripts were developed to streamline bulk data and image processing, enhancing efficiency and ensuring accuracy of datasets generated during expeditions. The increased productivity in the ALMNH:Inv collection sparked by the DigIn TCN has resulted in increased institutional support for the ALMNH:Inv collection, which will ensure the workflows for digitization and data dissemination established during the life of this grant will continue to be supported. As expected, digitization of the ALMNH:Inv collection has resulted in broader awareness of the valuable specimens in our collection and has increased the number of inquiries and loan requests from researchers.

The impact of this work extends beyond scientific research. DigIn provided hands-on training in biodiversity informatics for four undergraduate collections assistants and four graduate student interns, equipping them with essential skills in collection management and data curation and management. The educator workshops fostered a network of educators using collections data in teaching and facilitated collaboration between teachers and museum researchers. Thanks to the integration of our data into aggregators like GBIF, our efforts will support e.g., conservation efforts by providing reliable species distribution data, which will aid in the detection of biodiversity changes over time. As a part of DigIn, our team participated in University of Alabama outreach events and visits to local schools to engage and educate the public and middle school students about natural history collections and biodiversity. Although this grant has concluded, DigIn enabled ALMNH:Inv to develop a robust digitization workflow and train a highly efficient team of student assistants and interns, which are now supported by institutional resources, ensuring that our digitization efforts will continue at their current pace well beyond the life of this grant. Through DigIn, ALMNH:Inv is now a globally accessible, dynamic resource that will support scientific discovery for years to come.
